oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Crutchfield House and Civil War buildings
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: View of the front and side of Crutchfield House, post headquarters and hospital during the Civil War, and railroad depot in Chattanooga.

Slaves built the Union Depot in Chattanooga (also known as Chattanooga Union Station) between 1857-1859, and during the Civil War, the train card shed was used as an army hospital. In 1861, it was used as a hospital by Maj. Charles Anderson as a Confederate hospital, but was later used by Union Troops as a hospital. The original Crutchfield House (predecessor to The Read House Hotel) was built by Thomas Crutchfield from 1847-1848 and was the site of an incident between Jefferson Davis and William Crutchfield.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Railroad stations--Tennessee; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Hospitals
